item.title: Last look at Comet C/2020 F3 NEOWISE
item.description: This is a follow-up to my July 29 post. Comet NEOWISE has faded rapidly in the last eight days as it continues to move away from the sun and the earth.

item.title: Comet C/2020 F3 NEOWISE
item.description: Now rapidly moving away from both the sun and the earth, Comet NEOWISE (C/2020 F3) was only discovered on March 27 and turned out to be the brightest comet visible from the northern hemisphere since Comet Hale–Bopp in 1997. A week ago it was easily visible to the naked eye, but it has dimmed greatly since then.

item.title: Comet C/2019 Y4 ATLAS
item.description: Comet C/2019 Y4 ATLAS has been a big disappointment. It was discovered just four months ago, on December 28, 2019. Initially it brightened much more quickly than expected, and there were hopes that it might reach naked-eye visibility in late May when it will pass closest to the sun and to the earth. However its nucleus was observed to fragment by early April, and as a result it started getting dimmer instead of brighter. You can see pictures of the fragments taken by the Hubble Space Telescope by clicking on this link.
